text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- Bulgaria can gain some $5.8 billion net revenue over 30 years from a pipeline concession for transiting Russian gas through its territory, if the government grants the concession, visiting Russian Deputy Prime Minister Oleg Lobov said.

-- Bulgaria's state monopolist cigarette maker Bulgartabak holding is expected to submit a proposal to the Trade Ministry by December 20 for a 40 percent rise in cigarette prices, a company official said.
-- Bulgaria's Health Ministry said prices of Bulgarian-made medicines would be raised by some 50 percent effective from Monday as a result of a rise in fuel prices.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet debated the 1997 draft budget envisaging an introduction of a currency board system in the country but no decisions were taken.
The Finance Minister Dimitar Kostov said a government commission would discuss the final version of the draft with representatives of the International Monetary Fund.

-- The ruling Socialist party is not able to introduce succesfully a currency board system in Bulgaria because it has the support of only 13 to 16 percent of Bulgarians, the main opposition Union of Democratic Forces leader Ivan Kostov said.
-- Bulgaria had signed a preliminary protocol for grain imports from Russia and details of the deal are yet to be discussed by the two governments, a senior Russian government official said.
-- Bulgaria's Telecommunications Company (BTC) will submit a proposal to the cabinet to raise telephone charges by 40 percent effective from January 1, a BTC senior official said.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet has decided to peg fuel prices to the central bank's daily fixing for the German mark, the newspaper said without quoting sources.
